name: wafer production, fabricated, for integrated circuit | wafer, fabricated, for integrated circuit | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/6480/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 m2 of an electronic-grade silicon wafer used for integrated circuit or chip fabrication.The original input data for chemicals and elemental gases represents measures in grams per cm2 of input wafer. The information stems partly from an anonymous firm describing material input/output for a mid-sized, state-of-the art integrated circuit fabrication facility in Western Europe in 2000. The infrastructure is calculated for a company producing 40'000 200-mm wafers per month, each weighing 168 kg. The life-span of the facility is assumed to be 25 years, a photovoltaic cell factory is taken as proxy. 

From reception of process chemicals, process gases and silicon wafer at the factory gate. Describes the inputs of elemental gases like helium nitrogen or argon; deposition or dopant gases like silane, phosphine or arsine; etchants like ammonia, nitrous oxide, chlorine, hydrogen chloride or hydrofluoric acid; acids like nitric acid or sulfuric acid; photolithographic chemicals like acetone.

Further inventoried are electricity input for the whole wafer fabrication process (layering, patterning, doping, heat treatment), consumption of direct fossil fuels (natural gas), water consumption for the purification processes and the cooling, emissions to air (e.g. VOCs, PFC, HAPs, etc.), water and infrastructure.
category: C:Manufacturing/26:Manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products/261:Manufacture of electronic components and boards/2610:Manufacture of electronic components and boards

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The input data is based on a chip factory in Western Europe representing global average. Emissions, water and energy inputs are retrieved from three different wafer fabrication sites in the USA and one company in Central Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Wafer fabrication operation may take several steps, there are two major activities: ;-FEOL (Front End Of the Line);-BEOL (Back End Of the Line);In FEOL transistors and other devices are formed in the wafer surface. Companies use four basic operations in a large number of sequences and variations to produce specific microchips. ;- Layering: used to add thin layers to the wafer surface. These layers could be insulators, semiconductors, or conductors. They are of different materials (e.g. silicon dioxide or polycrystalline silicon) and grown or deposited by a variety of processes (e.g. thermal oxidation, chemical vapor deposition).;- Patterning: steps that results in the removal of selected portions of the added surface layers,  various physical parts of the transistors, diodes, capacitors or resistors are formed in and on the wafer surface, one layer at the time. The goal is to create the desired shapes in the exact dimensions required by the circuit design, and to locate them in their proper location on the wafer surface and in relation to the other parts. It is the most critical of the four basic operations. ;-Doping: puts specific amounts of electrically active dopants in the wafer surface through openings in the surface layers. It can be done by: thermal diffusion (wafer heated at about 1000 °C and exposed to vapors of the proper dopant), ion implantation (wafers loaded in one end of an implanter and dopant sources in the other);-Heat treatments: wafer is heated and cooled to achieve specific results;In BEOL, devices are wired together with metallization processes, and the circuit is protected with a final sealing layer. Alloying, is performed after metal patterning to ensure good electrical contact between the metal and the wafer surface, wafer sort of every chip to identify those that meet customer specifications.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Manufacturer information from literature and sustainability reports.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
The wafer fabrication is the processes required to prepare and process a high-grade silicon wafer to become an integrated circuit or microchip. Elemental gases, organic and inorganic chemicals, as well as a remarkable amount of high-purity water and energy are being consumed during wafer fabrication. Apart from that, high amounts of air emissions (e.g. VOCs), solid waste and waste water are produced during the different process steps.

flow.name: wafer, fabricated, for integrated circuit
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/26:Manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products/261:Manufacture of electronic components and boards/2610:Manufacture of electronic components and boards

exchanges.description:
Calculated Value, based on literature. Hydrogen fluoride is used as a proxy for corrosives and  inorganic  chemicals. It is calculated indirectly via the water usage. For corrosives the calculated ratio between sources is 6701.
Calculation: 3298/6701

For inorganic chemicals the calculated ratio between sources is 63585. It is considered that data are 10% of the total consumption and emissions of the entire Intel Company. For the calculation: 800 kg of all inorganic HAPs, 20 kg of Phosphine emissions and 0.62*0.435 kg (1 pound) = 0.27 kg of Arsine.
Calculation: (800-20.27)*0.1/63585

Further references:

AMD (2006) 2005 Corporate Responsibility Report. In, pp., Online-Version under: <http://www.amd.com/us-en/assets/content_type/DownloadableAssets/2005_Corporate_Responsibility_Report_Final.pdf>.

Intel Corporation (2005) Annual FPA Progress Report - Ocotillo.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Calculated Value, based on literature. A 55% process yeld was assumed. It is based on a amount of 0.505 kg of solid waste per cm2 of wafer input 
Calculation: (0.23+0.78)/2*10’000*(1/0.55)

Source: UNU/IAS (Eric Williams) 2000/United Nations University/Institute of Advanced Studies, 2000:  p.74 one 150 mm wafer creates 40.5 kg of waste (40.5 kg/ 176.1 cm2) = 0.23 kg/ cm2 and p.75 UNIDO/UNEP 4 kg/in2 = 0.78 kg/cm2 (older data based on 100 mm wafers)   Average of 0.23+0.78=0.505 kg taken.

exchanges.description:
Calculated Value, based on literature, calculated indirectly via the water usage. The calculated ratio between sources is 56456. 78 kg CFC-11
equals 97.5 kg CFC-113, ODP (ozone depletion potential) of CFC-113  is 0.8 of the potential of CFC-11.
Calculation: (1/0.8*78)/56456

Further references:
ST Microelectronics (2004) Chemical Content of Semiconductor Packaging. PDF from <http://www.stmicroelectronics.com/stonline/company/environm/report03/envi03.pdf>.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Calculated Value, based on literature. A 55% process yeld was assumed. It is based on a amount of 0.505 kg of solid waste per cm2 of wafer input 
Calculation: (0.23+0.78)/2*10’000*(1/0.55)

Source: UNU/IAS (Eric Williams) 2000/United Nations University/Institute of Advanced Studies, 2000:  p.74 one 150 mm wafer creates 40.5 kg of waste (40.5 kg/ 176.1 cm2) = 0.23 kg/ cm2 and p.75 UNIDO/UNEP 4 kg/in2 = 0.78 kg/cm2 (older data based on 100 mm wafers)   Average of 0.23+0.78=0.505 kg taken.

flow.name: waste, from silicon wafer production, inorganic
flow.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/382:Waste treatment and disposal/3822:Treatment and disposal of hazardous waste

exchanges.description:
Calculated Value, based on literature, calculated indirectly via the water usage. The calculated ratio between sources is 63585. It is considered that data are 10% of the total consumption and emissions of the entire Intel Company. Phosphine is used as a proxy for inorganic chemicals.
Calculation: 1060*0.1/63585

Further references:
Intel Corporation (2005) Annual FPA Progress Report - Ocotillo.
